results.title: In Panjshir, Few Signs of an Active Resistance, or Any Fight at All

results.title: A Celebrated Virtuoso on an Instrument She Wasn’t Meant to Play
results.abstract: The hallowed tradition of kora playing in Sona Jobarteh’s family passed down the male line. One of her teachers dismissed it as “an ethnic thing.” But it has brought her international acclaim.

results.title: Merkel Leaves the German Economy With Trouble Under the Hood
results.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel steered Europe through crises, and Germany has boomed during her tenure. But she has ducked changes needed to ensure the success lasts, analysts say.
results.byline: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy

multimedia.caption: During Chancellor Angela Merkel’s tenure, economists say, Germany has neglected digital infrastructure, bungled an exit from nuclear power and become dependent on exporting to China.

results.title: Taliban Seize Women’s Ministry Building for Use by Religious Police
results.abstract: Taliban leaders have turned the Kabul building that housed Afghanistan’s Ministry of Women’s Affairs into the offices for the religious police, an ominous portent for women’s rights.

multimedia.caption: The new Ministry of Invitation, Guidance and Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice, formerly the Ministry for Women’s Affairs, in Kabul. The compound still has murals depicting women, some now with desecrated faces, on the perimeter blast walls.

results.title: I.M.F. chief says claims she inflated China data at World Bank are ‘not true.’

org_facet: Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP

multimedia.caption: “I would ask staff to please check, double-check, triple-check, but never change, never manipulate what the data tells us,” Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, told staff on Friday.

results.title: Britain Signals Intent to Revert to the Imperial System

results.title: Ida Nudel, ‘Angel’ to Soviet Jews Seeking to Flee, Dies at 90

results.title: Floods, Hunger, Violence: A Power Struggle Is the Least of Haiti’s Worries.
results.abstract: In a country where food is scarce and the land can shake underfoot at any moment, political infighting is just one crisis among many.

multimedia.caption: A view of downtown Port-au-Prince last month shortly before a tropical storm, which came just days after an earthquake struck the country. These and other overlapping crises that Haitians have faced in recent months have tested their resilience.
multimedia.copyright: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times

results.title: Italy extends its health-pass requirement to cover most workers, public and private.
results.abstract: The new mandate that workers be able to show proof of vaccination, immunity or a recent negative test by mid-October is one of the most sweeping in Europe.
results.byline: By Gaia Pianigiani and Emma Bubola

multimedia.caption: A teacher, left, presented her health certificate, known as a Green Pass, to be checked by a school worker at the Isacco Newton high school in Rome on Monday.
A teacher, left, presented her health certificate, known as a Green Pass, to be checked by a school worker at the Isacco Newton high school in Rome on Monday.

results.title: African public health experts call for the U.N. General Assembly to speed the delivery of vaccines.
results.abstract: Only 2 percent of doses administered globally so far have been given in Africa, where one-sixth of the world’s people live, according to the W.H.O.

multimedia.caption: A Kenyan man received a dose of the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine, donated by Britain, at the Makongeni Estate in Nairobi in August.

results.title: At Least 9 Drown Swimming Off the Coast of Southern France
results.abstract: The victims had ventured into the waves at various beaches despite high seas stirred up by strong winds that formed perilous underwater swells.

multimedia.caption: A firefighter patrolling a beach on Thursday in La Grande Motte, near Montpellier, in southern France. The waters along the Mediterranean coast can be deceptively treacherous.

results.title: China says it has fully vaccinated 1 billion people.
results.abstract: The country stepped closer to its goal of inoculating 80 percent of its population of 1.4 billion by the end of the year.
results.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen

results.title: U.S. and Egypt Put Improving Egypt’s Human Rights on the Agenda
results.abstract: Both countries took steps aimed at improving Egypt’s poor human rights record, but rights advocates found them short of the mark.
results.byline: By Mona El-Naggar and Lara Jakes
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the United States Embassy in Cairo in May. On Tuesday, the State Department notified Congress that it was withholding $130 million in military aid until Egypt meets specific human rights benchmarks.
